bug.short_desc: use the thumbnail of the document as the window icon

long_desc.thetext:
Hi, this is a request for a window icon in evince.
Currently we have a generic window icon which makes it pretty impossible to determine one document from another opened in evince.
My original suggestion was to use the thumbnail of the first page of the document as the icon, however I started thinking that the thumbnail of the current page might be more appropriate.
Then later I realized that having the window icon changed based on the page is probably a pretty bad idea. :-) Reasoning: The icon is just for recognition to get back to the document from alt-tab view or maybe the window list. Changing this icon everytime a page changes would possibly have the icon change a lot and also not give a consitent recognition of the document from an icon (alt-tab) view.
So there's my reasoning for the first page.
A side note: I had also thought that if there were nice session support in evince for opening a document where you last closed it we might use that first page focussed, but that runs into the same problem as i discussed before.

Created an attachment (id=37798) Window Icon in Task Bar
Had a question about this, so this is one of the places where the document window icon would appear.

This would actually look pretty ugly, and certainly close to useless if you don't Alt-Tab that often (or not at all, like most non-techie users I see). Have you tried this with a couple of your PDFs? How does it look in the window list menu, or the tasklist?
Have you tried this with totem, for movie thumbnails? Depending on the size it needs to shrink to it could come out just looking like a bunch of junk, however if scaled right it might not.

The problem is that in the tasklist, or the window list, the icons would be pretty small (24x24 by default), making a lot of documents (legalese stuff for example) white papers with a grey smudge in the middle.

Hmm, I guess without a way to do smooth drawing and rendering of the thumbnail at a very small size this will look pretty ugly. I tested it out tonight on a number of thumbnails, it looks about as helpful as the thumbnail is (which is good), however it is shrunk to a size that's odd looking and even if it were generated at the smaller size it probably would still be useless.

[Switching to Thread 16384 (LWP 16328)] 0x080683be in Thumb::Thumb(XRef*, Object*) () (gdb) where #0 0x080683be in Thumb::Thumb(XRef*, Object*) () #1 0x080673c9 in pdf_document_thumbnails_get_dimensions(_EvDocumentThumbnails*, int, int, int*, int*) () #2 0x08072b54 in ev_document_thumbnails_get_dimensions () #3 0x0806461c in ev_sidebar_thumbnails_set_document () #4 0x08062fa9 in ev_sidebar_set_document () #5 0x0805dafa in ev_window_setup_document () #6 0x0805de38 in start_loading_document () #7 0x0805e13c in ev_window_open () #8 0x08064852 in load_files () #9 0x08064a0f in main () #10 0x40f497f7 in __libc_start_main () from /lib/i686/libc.so.6 (gdb) quit The program is running. bug.short_desc: eat CPU when opening some files

long_desc.thetext: you can find an example here: https://bugzilla.ubuntu.com/attachment.cgi?id=1286
This is reproducable with poppler gtk-splash-test. Please report it on freedesktop.org bugzilla.

Version details: mandrake 10.2 cooker
I realize that you don't want a myriad of options. However, screen estate being the most precious commodity in my computing world, I hope you might consider a mode to give me the most text per window footprint.
I use evince for pdflatex previews and want to proofread text on screen so that the bigger the size of the glyphs the more likely I am to find errors. 'Fit to page' wastes all the space in the magins and makes the text small. 'Fit to width' forces me into a whole different movement mode, with the page jumping around a whole lot. The new mode would allow me to:
1) open doc 2) fit to text 3) pgDown through the whole doc
so I could focus, as much as possible, on proofreading.
cheers, adrian

See the associated, pgup/down discussion in bug http://bugzilla.gnome.org/show_bug.cgi?id=170079
ciao, adrian

Thanks for the idea. That wish is already in bugzilla.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 169676 ***

bug.short_desc: Mozilla Firefox Ad from New York Times is not displayed correctly

long_desc.thetext:
Please describe the problem: Instead of ad text I can see only distorted letters with no similarity to actual add.
Steps to reproduce: 1. Download http://www.mozilla.org/press/nytimes-firefox-final.pdf 2. Open it in Evince 3. Cry.
Actual results: Some distorted rendering appear.
Expected results: Normal rendering. Adobe Acrobat Reader 5 shows that pdf without problems.
Does this happen every time? Yes.
Other information: Distro: Slackware -current. Attached GIMPed screenshot.

Created an attachment (id=36310) Slightly modified screenshot of bad rendering.
I slightly touched this shot in GIMP - I've pasted second misrendered page into it.
Can you please test the same file with gpdf (and possibly xpdf)?
With xpdf it looks garbled in exactly same way. With gpdf text is readable, except for peopke names on first page. And images are missing. t looks fine with Acrobat Reader 5.

Again (such as in bug 164754) the fonts are CID keyed ones.
As far as I understand, this bug is a duplicate of bug 164754 (and it should be marked as such).
ggv tells me it is not a valib PS file btw
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 164754 ***

Created an attachment (id=38643) Comparision of rendering by Evince and Adobe Reader 5
OK, fonts are now rendered almost properly (solid fill instead of gradient). But still, there is graphic missing. As you can see on this screenshot: - left is proper rendering by Adobe Reader 5 - "Firefox 1.0" text is a gradient and upper part of page is occupied by graphics. - right is Evince current as of 12 march 2005 - fonts are solid and firefox logo is missing.

ACK. We have a separate bug for the graphic problems with this file, bug 166879
You can add yourself to the cc list of that bug if you want to be notified when something changes in that bug.

attachment.desc: Slightly modified screenshot of bad rendering.
Comparision of rendering by Evince and Adobe Reader 5

bug.short_desc: Zoom behaves incorrectly after document reload

long_desc.thetext:
Version details: mandrake 10.2 cooker
When a document is re-loaded the zoom to fit width/page behave incorrectly. It seems that the state of the zoom is set incorrectly on re-load but that transitions from the initial state (post-reload) do work correctly.
1) load a pdf doc 2) zoom to fit page 3) zoom in (+) once 4) change the underlying doc, reload the doc => The doc is reloaded with a different setting than it had, zoomed in a little bit more. 5) zoom out (-) once => doc is in 'fit page' mode which is where it should be.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 169612 ***

http://www.netgear.com/pdf_docs/20050114_Fseries_ProSafematrix.pdf
*** Bug 169786 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

Created an attachment (id=38559) fix display of one page pdfs
The attached patch fixes the problem for me. But I think the source of the problem is somewhere else: Sometimes the first page of the document has index 1 and sometimes index 0.
Thanks Oliver! Your patch works for me as well. Evince was crashing on some rather trivial PDFs generated with LaTeX.
I checked in a fix for this. Test would be very welcome. I'll do a release as soon as I get some confirmation/test about this.
Works well with your fix, Marco.

0.1.9 works well on all my files. Incidentally, the attachments given on this bug tracker are CGIed into a file with extension .cgi, and Evince doesn't want to open a PDF with extension .cgi. Is this desired behavior, or is gnome_vfs_get_mime_type giving the wrong answer?

attachment.desc: This is the PDF that evince crashed on
fix display of one page pdfs
